description:
Objective: score most hits
Table version of basketball. Players direct the metal ball on the play field in such way to score the goal (2 points). Players figures are placed on small springs.
If active player scores ball possession changes; if basketball hoop is missed player proceeds where ball ended. If ball ends outside other player proceeds. Game ends after aggreed time or result.

Trifecta Poker is based on a Trifecta of winning Horse Cards as Win, Place, and Show.

A blend of Horse Racing, Classic Poker games and all original Artwork.

This set of Race Horse Playing cards is a real game changer. For instance every card is a Face Card and there are no Kings or Queens, Jacks nor Aces. The Royalty here or the Ace of the Race is represented by what horse is the Winner of the Race. These cards wear Silks not Suits.

This is the only game that tells you the Winners before you Start. The only question is who holds the Winning hand. The objective of the Play is to determine if You hold a Winning hand and have a chance to take home the Cash. The Rules are Simple but you can't Win if you don't Try and it's obviously better if you Trifecta!

The rules are simple in the basic form of play however, all sorts of other cards games can be played with this new game.
Here are the rules:

The Rules
Trifecta Poker Hand Rankings

Trifecta Poker can be played using almost any variation of common Poker Play rules. The Key to Trifecta Poker is that the winning hand is based on a Trifecta of winning Horse Cards. 

Dealer shuffles the 52 Cards and draws 3 different Horse Cards in a vertical display outward from the POT known as the Trifecta Flop. After each play the cards are shuffled and a new Trifecta Flop is drawn. The First Horse drawn is the Winning Horse, the 2nd is the Place and the 3rd is the Show - aka WPS. or a Superfecta game a 4th Horse is drawn. Duplicate Horse cards if they appear in the Flop are returned to the deck. Dealer then re-shuffles the remaining deck and deals 5 cards to each player. Players may now hold pat their original cards or draw from one to four new cards from the deck. The Player with the highest combinations of Trifecta, Quinella, or WPS card combinations wins. A Trifecta is all three winning horses, a Quinella is the Win and Place horses, and the WPS are any horses in the money. WPS combinations are ranked by the highest number of Horse cards in the money without a Trifecta or Quinella.

All Trifecta Poker hand rankings can be improved by also holding typical Poker combinations as shown below:

    For instance no. 1 : A Trifecta with a pair of any horses beats a Trifecta with no pair.
    For instance no. 2: A Win horse with three of a kind beats a Win horse with a pair.
    If NO players hold WPS Cards typical Poker Hand rankings are won as follows:
    Four of a Kind - Four of the same Horse cards.
    Full House- Three of a kind and a pair. The player with the higher value three of a kind, wins in the event of a tie. If both players have the same three of a kind then the player with the highest pair wins.
    Straight -Five cards of any horses in ascending order with the higher straight wins the tie.
    Three of a Kind- Simply three cards of the same horse.
    Two Pairs of Horses - The player holding the highest pair takes the pot in the event that more than one player is holding two pairs. If two players are both holding the same two pair then the player with the highest fifth horse (i.e. the kicker) takes the pot.
    One Pair of Horses-Two cards of the same horse.
    HIGH Horse -Highest card takes all in the event there is a complete absence of the above hands.

Players draw a category card and read the topic. Then they draw the letter-card instead of turning the wheel like in original Pim-Pam-Pet. Everyone is trying as quickly as possible to find a word that matches the subject and with that specific letter in start, in end or in middle of the word etc.

A good answer is rewarded by a chip in the color of the question. 
Who at the end of the game has scored the most points is the winner.

Players place the picture board at the middle of the table.
In his turn player spins the spinner and if the arrow stops and points the letter all players look at the picture to search for something that starts with that letter.
First to points something and shouts it scores a point.

The ï¬rst player to reach the pre-agreed points wins the game!

Peppa Pig Fairground Ride Game is fun and exciting 3D game of musical air-swings – but with a fun and exciting twist for young children.

The game begins when each player chooses their Peppa Pig character to play with, and places it on a seat on the fairground ride. The youngest player begins by pressing down on the red button top and everyone watches the air swings spin round and around and listening to the fun musical tune that will be playing. The aim of the game is to be the last player sat on the air swings – but if you Peppa Pig figurine lands next to a red ‘Hop Off’ space, then they must hop off the ride and try to guess where the empty seat will land next. Did you guess it right? If not, don’t worry, you have until the winner is left on the swings to hop back on the ride.

Players try and jump the Peppa Pig playing counters into the muddy puddle on the table in the middle of the game box and the first player to do this is the winner of the round. You can play as many rounds as you like, because after all, Peppa loves nothing more than jumping in the biggest and muddiest puddle she can find!

This trivia/party game can be played in two teams or with at least two players. The topic is "good manners".

The object of the game is to win as many cards as possible, by answering questions about good manners and performing tasks from the activity cards. Each card is worth 1 point. The game is over when the first player reaches the goal box. The player who has won the most cards/points is the winner.

Activity cards come in two types: "Picture Memo" and "Confusing Letters". "Picture Memo" means the active player has to memorize the picture on the card. After 30 seconds, the player on the left makes up a question about the picture, which the active player has to answer. In the "Confusing Letters" activity, there are three words on the card, with their letters jumbled. The active player has to guess the words while the timer is running.

“Quirinalopoli. Rush for the Presidency” is a political version of a roll-and-move gamey styled like the Game of Goose enclosed to “Il Borghese” magazine in the summer 1997: it consisted of a board and the miniatures of eight Italian politicians of the day to be used as playing pieces.  Players roll the dice and move their figures and respond to spaces on the board.


“Quirinalopoli” è un Gioco dell’Oca a tema politico allegato alla rivista “Il Borghese” nell’estate 1997: oltre alla plancia di gioco sono state realizzate anche le miniature di otto “protagonisti della Seconda Repubblica” da utilizzarsi come pedine.

“Tr3cento. A day in Bolzano, 1300 A.D.” is a historically-themed didactic game made on the occasion of a gothic painters exhibition that took place in the Italian town of Bolzano in the year 2000.

The aim of the game is experiencing everyday’s life in the XIV century’s Bolzano.

Before starting, every player draws a card showing a different character and, by rolling a die and answering questions (each character has an own set), needs to make a whole round on the map in order to win the game.


“Tr3cento. Una giornata nella Bolzano del 1300” è un gioco didattico a tema storico realizzato per un’esposizione di pittori gotici allestita a Bolzano nel 2000.

Scopo del gioco è sperimentare la vita quotidiana nella Bolzano del Trecento.

All’inizio ogni giocatore pesca un personaggio da un mazzo di carte e - ora lanciando un dado, ora rispondendo a diverse domande (cambiano da personaggio a personaggio) - deve completare un giro della mappa per vincere.

Each player chooses a story. Shuffle the 32 cards and place them face down on the table. The oldest player begins the game by looking one of the cards. If the card is part of his story player takes it and puts it in his book of images. The player may continue his turn until he looks the card not belonging to his story. He shows the card to other and ends his turn. The first player who completed his picture with 8 cards is the winner.
remarks:
pretty same game approach like Memo Extra Picturebook Boys, but different box, materials & target group

Monopoly with a Bobcat construction equipment theme.

From the box: With Bobcat of Futureville, you too can live the life of a Bobcat dealer.  Purchase Bobcat of Futureville and other dealerships for your chnace to lead the market.  Achieve Brand Orange facility status and dig your way to Bobcat of Dealertown.  Add another sales specialist and increase your market share and win money!  But gamble wisely--if you land in the wrong neighborhood, you could be buying trucks and trailers from the dealer next door.  Worse, if you don't take care of the customer, it'll cost you.

Translated box black blurb

School Order Rep has come to investigate any personal items student have brought to school. As a student, you must treat the Order rep correctly so as to avoid punishment.

How?

Well, by seeing to that your BL fanzines aren't "unnecessary" items, of course!

User summary
A simple card game consisting of different types of attractive boys, guys and men (anime style). Players take turns being the Order rep, who decides what preferences are OK, and the remaining players (students) try to play their cards so that they match them as much as possible. A game of deduction and creative guessing. And laughs.

The game also comes with identical rules called "Model Men", where the players try to guess what combination of model will sell the next fashion mag.

In the small town of Palermo a series of murders are disturbing the peaceful citizens. Mafia is everywhere and every night the number of victims grows higher. The citizens of Palermo try to discover the culprits. But who can they trust? Noone knows who may be behind the murders. One thing is certain though:

Everybody has a role to play in this story!

Palermo: The Big Cleanup is a new version of the well known party game (known mostly as Werewolf) in which the innocent citizens try to dig out the mafia members among them. What makes this game different from most of the other Werewolf versions out there is that ALL the innocent citizens have a hidden role with a special ability that will help them identify the criminals. Moreover, action cards handed to the players give them more options to gather information, bluff or discover identities!

But when you trust noone, how effectively can you use all that?


Στην Î®συχη πÏŒλη του ΠαλÎ­ρμο μια σειρÎ¬ απÏŒ δολοφονÎ¯ες διαταρÎ¬σσουν την ηρεμÎ¯α των πολιτÏŽν. Η ΜαφÎ¯α Î­χει απλÏŽσει τα δÎ¯χτυα της και κÎ¬θε βρÎ¬δυ ο αριθμÏŒς των θυμÎ¬των μεγαλÏŽνει.Οι πολÎ¯τες του ΠαλÎ­ρμο πασχÎ¯ζουν να ανακαλÏψουν τους ενÏŒχους. ÎŒμως ποιον να εμπιστευτοÏν; ΚανεÎ¯ς δεν ξÎ­ρει ποιος μπορεÎ¯ να κρÏβεται απÏŒ πÎ¯σω. Îˆνα εÎ¯ναι σÎ¯γουρο ÏŒμως:

ÎŒλοι παÎ¯ζουν κÎ¬ποιο ρÏŒλο σε αυτÎ® την ιστορÎ¯α!

Το "ΠαλÎ­ρμο: Το ΜεγÎ¬λο ΞεκαθÎ¬ρισμα" εÎ¯ναι μια νÎ­α εκδοχÎ® του γνωστοÏ παιχνιδιοÏ παρÎ­ας στο οποÎ¯ο οι αθÏŽοι πολÎ¯τες προσπαθοÏν να ανακαλÏψουν τους μαφιÏŒζους ανÎ¬μεσα τους. Σε αντÎ¯θεση ÏŒμως με Î¬λλες εκδÏŒσεις του παιχνιδιοÏ, εδÏŽ ΟΛΟΙ οι αθÏŽοι πολÎ¯τες Î­χουν Î­να δικÏŒ τους ρÏŒλο με μια κρυφÎ® ιδιÏŒτητα που θα τους βοηθÎ®σει να ανακαλÏψουν τους ενÏŒχους. ΕπιπλÎ­ον, κÎ¬ρτες ενεργειÏŽν δÎ¯νουν νÎ­ες δυνατÏŒτητες για συλλογÎ® πληροφοριÏŽν, μπλÏŒφες και αποκαλÏψεις ενÏŒχων!

ÎŒταν ÏŒμως κανεÎ¯ς δε μπορεÎ¯ να επιστευτεÎ¯ κανÎ­ναν, πÏŒσο αποτελεσματικÎ¬ θα μπορÎ­σετε να αξιοποιÎ®σετε ÏŒλα αυτÎ¬;

Children's game that is very much in the camp of a favourite German game called Malefiz ('Barricade in English').

Each player gets two identical playing pieces. The board features paths from the bottom up to Pride Rock at the top. But the paths get closer together as they go up the board which results in playing pieces getting a little tight to move. Thus, if you land exactly on another playing piece, that piece must return to the bottom row and start again.

Movement is by a die (that includes a spot symbol on two faces). Should you roll a spot you can place a jungle maker on to the board. Or, you can move one on the board to a new location. These jungle markers are blockers which cannot be jumped.

The winner is the first player to get one of his pieces on to the Pride Rock square by an exact throw of the die.

The board game, Moneture, illustrates operation of the National Bank of Serbia  under inflation targeting regime. Players take the role of the Governor and apply appropriate measures to influence the actual situation, win or lose the number of points and maintain inflation within the target range. The points to be won in the game represent success features: inflation value, dinar value and public trust. In addition, for membership in the EU monetary system, three conditions have to be met (Price Stability, Financial Stability and Independence of the National Bank). The winner of the game is the player who first completes all the specified tasks and reaches the end of  the inner circle of the board - average inflation of the European Union.

In the abstract strategy game Rondo, players try to score as many points as possible by placing tokens on numbered spaces on the game board, with the board consisting of two concentric rings of numbered spaces and multiple spokes connecting these rings and the center of the board. (The game board is double-sided, with different values on each side.) The numbers come in five colors, and players start the game by drawing two tokens (also in five colors) from a bag and placing them on a rack, thereby hiding the color of the tokens from other players.

On a turn, a player can either (1) play as many tokens as they want in a continuous chain, with the first token being placed next to an occupied space or the center space, then drawing one token from the bag or (2) drawing two tokens and placing none on the board. A player can hold at most five tokens on their rack.

When a player places tokens, the color of the token must match the space being covered; immediately score the points shown on this space. A player can choose to place a non-matching token face down on a space in order to reach another space, but they score no points for the face-down token. Alternatively, a player can play multiple tokens of the same color on a matching space and score the listed number of points for each token placed.

The game board has a number of dark grey spaces on it. The game ends at the end of the round in which all of these spaces are occupied or a player cannot draw enough tokens to complete their turn. The player with the most points wins!

A push your luck dice rolling game.

Object: "All players try to accumulate the highest number of points per turn, which uhen added to their score, gives them the necessary 10,000 points to win."

Equipment: box, instructions, scoresheets, dice cup and six dice (marked blank, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5).

Scoring: blank = 50, 1=100, 3 of a kind = varies (2-5 = die x 100, blank = 500, 1 = 1000), straight (blank, 1-5) = 1000, and 6 of a kind = 3 of a kind x 3.

Tactical combat game based on Japanese mecha animation series Mobile Suit Gundam ZZ. The game covers combat in and around space colonies.

Each unit represent one humanoid weapon called mobile suit (MS). Unit ability is written on separate data cards.

Each player control one or few MS and aims at the destruction of the opponent MS.

Players writes down the plan of the movement and the battle in the log. Then, that is disclose and resolve at simultaneous.

All of the eligible young men (and many of the not-so-young) seek to woo the princess of Tempest. Unfortunately, she has locked herself in the palace, and you must rely on others to take your romantic letters to her. Will yours reach her first?

Love Letter is a game of risk, deduction, and luck for 2–4 players. Your goal is to get your love letter into Princess Annette's hands while deflecting the letters from competing suitors. From a deck with only sixteen cards, each player starts with only one card in hand; one card is removed from play. On a turn, you draw one card, and play one card, trying to expose others and knock them from the game. Powerful cards lead to early gains, but make you a target. Rely on weaker cards for too long, however, and your letter may be tossed in the fire!

Number 4 in the Setting: Tempest Shared World Game Series

Tactical space combat game based on Japanese robotech animation series "Blue Comet SPT Layzner".

Each unit represent a SPT(Super Powered Tracer, robotech name in this universe). Unit ability is written on the data cards.

Each player control one or few SPT and aims at the destruction of the opponent SPT.

Players writes down the plan of the movement and the battle in the log. Then, that is disclose and resolve at simultaneous. The law of the inertia acts on the movement in the outer space. Feature of this game is a rule of search operation using the dual map.

From the objective in the rule book:  "The object of the game is to depart from home, arrive at the hunting camp, go on a gobbler hunt and be the first to "Bag" your gobbler."  Players roll a die to move along the paths in the woods.  Spaces include such activities as "Gas Stop", "Forgot Flashlight", and "Stuck in Swamp", all of which result in losing a turn.  There are also 3 decks of cards: Road Chance, Hunt Chance, and Phone Chance.  Also from the rule book, to win the game, "A player must roll the EXACT NUMBER ON THE DIE to get his gobbler or be lucky enough to draw the 'WINNER CARD' from the green chance pile."

Objective: be the first completing your puzzle
 - acting by turns -
arrange puzzle tile by colour and build a pile for each player,
symbols on top.
Each player rolls the die:
There is a matching symbol on top of your pile - take it and try to complete your puzzle; if your die shows 'Das kleine Ich bin Ich = joker', take the tile, too, but the 'moon' symbol let you sleep - lose one turn.

Grow is a solitaire game where the player guides a growing forest towards safety from the lumber industry.

The Player builds his/her tree through a series of rounds using hex tiles representing branches and leaves. The leaf tiles provides energy (used as Action point) for the player to spend growing his tree further or expanding his tree population.

As the player's tree grows bigger, it also becomes more profitable to cut down. The lumberjack token will become more active and more powerful as the game progresses. The player loses the game when there's no more trees for the lumberjack to cut down!

The game is a free Print-and-play game available to anyone! Counters are provided but standard wooden cube are suggested for convenience.

The HomeVesting playing board has two six-sided playing courses: the outer, purple “Rehabilitation” course, and the inner, orange “Selling” course. Each course represents a different stage of the investing process.

The outer “Rehabilitation” course is where we initially buy, carry, and fix up our properties. The game always starts on this outer course.

The inner “Selling” course is where we seek deals to sell our investments and cash out. Players individually move onto the inner Selling path as they complete their Rehabilitation process.

Summary of the Game

Players select investment properties, begin on their individual colored Start spot, and take turns moving their pawn around the outer Rehabilitation path to develop their properties.

Eventually, each player will complete their Rehabilitation phase, progress to their colored Start spot on the inner Selling course, then proceed around the Selling course to seek a deal for cashing out and selling their investments.

Play continues until only one player remains which has not settled all debts and cashed out of the game. All players have the option of short-selling and cashing out of the game at any time before completing their full rehabilitation and selling process, which establishes their final cash position. But a final remaining player is always forced into a short-sell to end the game. All players then evaluate their final cash position. The player finishing with the most money wins.

UNRELEASED GAME

    
    
         Note that all details for this game are preliminary. If you have information about this game, you are invited to edit this section or submit corrections.

    


Chez Guild blends the characters from the web series The Guild with the Chez Geek series of card games, with characters trying to collect slack while annoying their roommates and keeping them from achieving their goals.

Paul Koenig’s Market-Garden is a series of small-format, competitive introductory-level wargames covering the critical first three days of Operation Market-Garden, where the Allies attempted to seize a series of bridges in Holland and end WWII before Christmas. Each game in the series covers a separate bridge: Arnhem, Eindhoven, and Nijmegen. As a player, you must command your German or Allied forces so as to capture key objectives on the board while keeping your casualties down (and your opponent’s casualties up).

Nijmegen Bridge is the third and final game in the Market-Garden series, covering the events happening at this vital river crossing from September 17th-19th, 1944. The central Nijmegen sector of the attack crossed an arm of the Rhine that could not be bridged easily. If the US 82nd Airborne failed to capture the Nijmegen cross, the advance of XXX Corps would be checked and Operation Market-Garden would fail.

With plenty of decision making and Optional Rules to extend gameplay and realism, the Allied advance into Germany hangs in the balance at Nijmegen Bridge!

Game Data:

Complexity: 3 on a 9 scale
Solitaire Suitability: 8 on a 9 scale
Unit scale: Each unit is 1 company to regiment, each hex is 0.6 kilometers, each (day) turn is about 4.5 hours, and each (night) turn is about 10 hours.

Matching card game with topic "History"

There are info or picture on the middle of the card and multiple patterns on the edges. Two or more cards match if at least one pattern fits on all cards.

In the beginning of round multiple cards are drawn from the table. Players who first declare the matching cards (based by their knowlidge or seeing the matching pattern) get the cards.
If there are no matched cards found the new cards are drawn.

Player with the most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Matching card game with topic "Human Body"

There are info or picture on the middle of the card and multiple patterns on the edges. Two or more cards match if at least one pattern fits on all cards.

In the beginning of round multiple cards are drawn from the table. Players who first declare the matching cards (based by their knowlidge or seeing the matching pattern) get the cards.
If there are no matched cards found the new cards are drawn.

Player with the most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

From the publisher: Characters from the hit movie, Star Trek, beam down to your HeroClix game! Completely compatible with the core HeroClix Rules system, The Star Trek HeroClix: Tactics Away Team 7-Pack includes pre-painted figures of Kirk, Spock, McCoy, Uhura, Scotty, Sulu, and Chekov, each incorporating a dual-dial design to provide 14 different playable HeroClix dials.

In Scheibenkleister one player tries to describe a word, term or person that the other players then need to guess – well, most of the other players. One or two opponents are trap makers who also know the word to be described; they try to foresee how the explainer will go about describing the word and lay down traps by secretly writing down two "trap" words each. If either the explainer or one of the guessers uses one of these words, the trap maker who wrote the word scores.

If anyone says a trap word, all trap words are revealed, and the guessers now have one final guess at the solution. Now a correct guess will score points for the trap makers rather than the explainer. Thus, the explainer's challenge is trying to avoid using "obvious words" – which often results in an explanation that is severely cryptical and not very to the point.

Test yourself. Do you know everything you need to know? With this super fun quiz you will practice all the courses you get in your group. 600 questions alternating questions and answers. With explanations and illustrations. For each group - from 3 to 8 - has its own quiz.

Topics: language - count - History - Society - Geography - Earth, space and environment - physics and technology - nature - traffic - English

The questions are on the left flaps, the answers on the right flaps. Turn the right flap to the answer.

Who answers correctly get a point. Winner is the player with the most point.

Test yourself. Do you know everything you need to know? With this super fun quiz you will practice all the courses you get in your group. 600 questions alternating questions and answers. With explanations and illustrations. For each group - from 3 to 8 - has its own quiz.

Topics: language - count - History - Society - Geography - Earth, space and environment - physics and technology - nature - traffic - English

The questions are on the left flaps, the answers on the right flaps. Turn the right flap to the answer.

Who answers correctly get a point. Winner is the player with the most point.

Test yourself. Do you know everything you need to know? With this super fun quiz you will practice all the courses you get in your group. 600 questions alternating questions and answers. With explanations and illustrations. For each group - from 3 to 8 - has its own quiz.

Topics: language - count - History - Society - Geography - Earth, space and environment - physics and technology - nature - traffic - English

The questions are on the left flaps, the answers on the right flaps. Turn the right flap to the answer.

Who answers correctly get a point. Winner is the player with the most point.

In Card City – part of Alban Viard's "Small City" trilogy of games, which includes the similar but three-dimensional Town Center – you will take on the role of the newly sworn-in Mayor. Your job is to encourage the growth of the residential, commercial, industrial and cultural districts that make up your home and to satisfy the demands of the city's residents. Card City includes six type of cards: Residences, Commercials, Industries, Leisure, Parking and City Hall. The game is divided into ten rounds, and each round consists of five phases:


     Players gain two new buildings (i.e., two cards) through an "I cut, you choose" game mechanism that includes hidden cards.
     Each player constructs the new buildings in his city according to zoning laws.
     When the environment is favorable, residential and commercial districts attract new citizens, and the cities begin to evolve.
     Players earn money from their city thanks to their commercial districts.
     The first player position changes.


At the end of the game, a district of one residence card scores 1 victory point (VP), a district of two residence cards scores 1+2 VPs, a district of three residence cards scores 1+2+3 VPs, and so on. In addition, each five money left is worth 1 VP. If the player has not finished his city, he earns negative points!

"Can Superboy Escape The Deadly Green Kryptonite?" Board has great action scene showing Superboy with spaceship as missiles fly toward him, and Krypto rides a rocket at the corner. The game ends on a "Kryptonite" square. There is a spinner attached to the cardboard insert and from the board it appears to be a simple spin and move game.

This was one of three games published by Hasbro in 1965 - one each for Batman, Superman and Superboy. SUPERBOY appears to be quite rare and is clearly valued by collectors.

This wine-themed trivia/party game can be played in two teams or with at least two players.
The object of the game is to win as many cards as possible, by answering questions about wine and performing tasks from the activity cards. Each card is worth 1 point. The first player to reach the finish space on the board wins the game.

Activity cards come in two types: "Picture Memo" and "Sparkling Letters". "Picture Memo" means the active player has to memorize the picture on the card. After 30 seconds, the player on the left makes up a question about the picture, which the active player has to answer. In the "Sparkling Letters" activity, there are three words on the card, with their letters jumbled. The active player has to guess the words while the timer is running.

Doctor Faustus made a pact with the demon, Mephistopheles, to have power over all demons and so become the most powerful magician of all time. You, too, have entered into such a pact, but can you really control what you have unleashed or will they take control of you?

Secrets are power and temptation! Battle with other magicians to ensure that you, and only you, escape the price for such power: Damnation!

Faustus is a game of secrets and temptation. In this game for 3 to 6 players, you take on the role of a magician summoning demons onto yourself and casting them at other magicians whilst tempting them with your hidden secrets. But only one can escape damnation. Only one! One goes free else all are damned!

With two versions of the game and optional rules, this game can be played by both novice and experienced gamers. In the Basic version of the game all that matters on the demons are the numbers; keep your numbers low and doom the rest. In the Advanced game you experience the full power of the demons under your command with each of the 40 Demons offering a unique power that is yours to command while they are in bound to your Pact.

As in its parent game Kakerlakenpoker, Kakerlakenpoker Royal has nothing to do with poker – except that the game is all about bluffing, but with cards showing cockroaches, rats, and stink bugs instead of queens, 10s, and aces. To set up the game, shuffle the deck and deal the cards out to players. On a turn, a player takes one card from his hand, lays it face down on the table, slides it to a player of his choice, and declares a type of critter, e.g., "Stink bug". The player receiving the card either:


    Accepts the card, says either "true" or "false", then reveals the card. If this player is wrong in her claim, she keeps the card on the table in front of her face up; if she is right, the player who gave her the card places it face up before him.



    Passes the card to another player, peeking at it first, then keeping it face-down and either saying the original type of critter or saying a new type. This new player again has the choice of accepting the card or passing it, unless the card has already been seen by all other players in which case the player must accept it and make a true/false claim.


The game ends when a player has no cards to pass on his turn or when a player has four cards of the same critter on the table in front of him. In either case, this player loses and everyone else wins.

To this, Kakerlakenpoker Royal adds new rules and new nasty "royal" critters to create more options for players during the game.

Object: The object of the game is to travel from Pasedena, through the many challenges of life as a genius, and ultimately arrive in the Nomination Zone, where you might just win as Emmy.

To Begin: Play "Rock, paper Scissors, Lizard, Spock" to determine who goes first (scissors cut paper, paper covers rock, rock crushes lizard, lizard poisons spock, spock vaporizes rock, rock crushes scissors). Each player takes a turnspinning the wheel and moving forward the number of spaces the spinner lands on.

Winning The Game: The first player to reach the Emmy nomination zone wins the game and has bragging rights for one year. They must attend all parties and pose for red-carpet photos. There are no guarantees that the funniest player will win the game, or that the winner will win again next time.

Triovision Master challenges players to move quickly and create certain combinations of shapes.

To start, the nine tokens – three cubes, three cylinders and three pawns, with red, blue and yellow versions of each – are placed randomly on the playing area: a field of 17 squares in a rough cross. Ten cards are revealed from the deck, with each card showing a pattern of colors and shapes in a particular arrangement. The backside of the card on top of the deck shows one of the nine tokens.

Everyone plays simultaneously. Players attempt to form one of the patterns shown on the cards by moving the specific piece indicated on the card back to any empty space on the game board. If the player does this correctly, she claims the card; if not, she's out for the round. Once someone claims a card, the top card of the deck is flipped, revealing a new pattern and the piece that now must be moved.

The first player to collect twelve cards wins.

A game in the Mancala family adapted from Tschuba with a novel starting position. Associated 1891 US patent: number 448,574.

Description following provided by Milton Bradley prior to 1897.

Chuba is an adaptation from a rude game of Eastern Africa which is greatly enjoyed by the natives, who squat on the ground, and play in holes scooped out of the sand, using shells, young coconuts, etc., for counters, which they move from hole to hole.
As now presented to the civilized world for its diversion, Chuba is a game of skill for two players. It is made up of a board with 4 parallel rows or pockets, 11 in each row, and 60 small beads used as men or counters.

...

The winner is the player who captures all his opponent's men."

Will the game board tip down or not? That's the question players face each turn in KIPP X, a captivating and challenging balance game that's yet easy to play. Just place a wooden block on the cross-seesaw and that's it – if it were not for the tipping.

To win KIPP X, you must be the first to get rid of all your blocks. To do this, you carefully position them one at a time on one of the lifted-up halves of the cross-seesaw. At some point, however, the weight becomes too much and the cross-seesaw tips down. If this happens, you must take any block(s) that fall off. Thus, you can't be too bold when placing blocks on the upraised planks – but maybe you can place just one more block...

Reimplements

    Kippit

Welcome to the world of Glory on the Pitch, brought to you by Diggin Deep Sports.  With Glory on the Pitch, you can re-create a full soccer match in about ten minutes, complete with the following:
Complete list of goal scorers, time of goals, and assists
Complete set of stats for selected players (Goals, Assists, Shots, Shots on Goal, Yellow Cards, Red Cards)
Complete keeper stats
In game strategies (Who to start? / When to sub? / Who to sub?)
Team Formations (Heavy offense / Heavy Defense / Balanced Attack)
For players that only play one half...Which half to play?
Individual cards means you can have draft leagues, and not be locked into stock teams.
 Within five minutes, you’ll have a final score complete with total shots on goal (per half).  You also have the option of tracking the stats of up to three players from each squad.  An entire match along with stats for certain players can be played in about ten to fifteen minutes.

Basically a "trouble style" game with cards.  Classic Moves was developed in the early 1990's by Moore and Moore Industries of London, Ontario.  Players begin with 4 marbles in a "safe" zone, and they must be moved around the board to the player's "Home Base".

Movement is accomplished with a 56 card deck, with numbers 1-12, and a number of "wild" cards.

There is a centre "shortcut" that can also be utilized.

Players can also play with a partner, assisting them once their marbles are "home"

The game contains 500 history cards from five categories which explore the "people, events, documents, principles and faith that have contributed to the founding of the United States".  Each card provides 'content-rich' answers (and pictures) that are sourced from over 100 books and 100s of online resources.

The game not only teaches America's history, but the humor in the game board and "social justice" cards draw a clear contrast between the founding roots of this country and the direction the nation has taken over the past 100 years.  The game was added to Glenn Beck's Marketplace in August, 2013. http://marketplace.theblaze.com/we-the-people-games-home

Players advance their pawns along the outside "semi-capitalist" square track until they lose their starting cash.  They are then required to mortgage their home and move to the inside circle or "path of social justice."  Stars are earned by answering the history cards correctly and lost through porkulus taxes.  The objective of the game is to be the player with the most stars when the first player goes broke on the inside track. The game takes about 1.5 to 2 hours to play.

A Princess-Lillifee themed travel game for two players.

The game comes in a metal box, whose lid also functions as the game board. It shows a grid of 4x7 squares and two starting spaces. On the grid are placed 28 magnetic flower pieces. Players take turns rolling a die. If the active player rolls a flower colour, he/she may move his/her player piece (also magnetic) until it reaches a flower of the corresponding colour. Pieces may only be moved either vertically or horizontally, and it may not jump over the other player's piece or the rose piece. If it reaches a flower of the colour on the die roll, the player wins that flower. If he can't reach a flower of the current colour, he/she may move their piece to an empty space. If a player rolls the rose symbol, he gets to move the rose piece. The rose can only be plucked once all the other flowers have been taken. In this phase of the game, there are no more die rolls. Each player gets to move once per round. While the other flowers are worth one point, the rose is worth three points.
The game ends when all flowers have been plucked. The player with the most points wins the game.

In Frontier Apocalypse, the world famous gunfight at the O.K Corral never happens. The night before, the unspeakable happens and the world was forever changed. Some blamed the South, some blamed the North, some blamed England, some blamed God or the Devil, but no one really knew what happened or why. But somehow humanity was able to survive the pulverizing chunks of moon rock that struck the planet; somehow humanity survived the various super volcanoes, massive radioactive solar flares and other terrible apocalyptic events. Frontier Apocalypse takes place over 100 years after that unspeakable event. In Frontier Apocalypse the Wild West never ended, it just got Wilder!

Frontier Apocalypse: The Hermit's Expedition is a solo Role Playing board/card game in the vein of games like Dungeon, Talisman, Chainsaw Warrior, and Dungeoneer. The player creates a character rolling dice, and then explores a post apocalyptic wild west by flipping cards that either reveal territories, critters, contraptions or various other events or points of interest. There are also boards to help with organization of character stats, gear and the game world. The game has several randomly chosen Expeditions that the player will need to complete with their character in order to win.Combat versus enemies is resolved by the character stats and contraptions and dice rolling. The player wins by completing their Expedition before running out of supplies or getting defeated the by various strange and weird critters who inhabit the Frontier Apocalypse world.

Realism is a money-based board game which is easy to play at the basic level with a subtle form of competition where, unlike other money games, winners do not succeed at the expense of other players, so everyone can enjoy the game.  A realistic game which makes players differentiate between needs and wants and encourages them to analyze their risk and limit their exposure.

The object of the game is to try to become a virtual millionaire by buying property, shares & other assets. The players have jobs, can invest, take out loans and buy insurance.  During play there are personal and market events to cope with.

This game is particularly relevant in these difficult financial times, as it encourages individuals to think more deeply about the financial decisions they make.

The game is aimed at adults and the family and helps the players learn about investment and spot the difference between "good" debt and "bad" debt. While playing they can build up their income with good investments and try to avoid buying costly luxuries.

The winner is the player with the most net assets when play finishes.

Every year, thousands of salmon are compelled to leave the ocean and return to the river of their birth. This perilous journey can span hundreds of miles and is fraught with danger. Strong rapids, waterfalls, hungry bears, and eagles all await the salmon on their quest to spawn. Only the most fit will complete the salmon run!

Salmon Run is a fast-paced racing game in which you'll maneuver your salmon upriver, avoiding obstacles and jumping over waterfalls. Behold the immense power of the river's currents! Avoid ferocious bears! Beware of stealthy eagles, waiting to snatch victory from your hand! Most of all, pace yourself to avoid debilitating fatigue. Salmon Run features:


    Deck-building: The path you choose upriver will determine which cards you may add to your swimming deck. Enhance your swimming ability by gaining powerful swim cards!
    Player Interaction: Acquire cards to unleash hungry bears and eagles on your opponent's salmon! Unlock the power of the river's raging rapids and strong currents!
    Fatigue: Overexertion leads to the build-up of fatigue which will slow you down!
    Modular boards: Experience a new river each game! The river's difficulty and length can be customized to your liking!
